docs.title: Home
docs.text: Early Design Carbon Alternatives (EDCA) — a tool to compare structural systems by material take-offs, cost and embodied carbon at early design stages.

docs.title: Use Cases and Limitations
docs.text: EDCA helps you: - parse control files and inputs - compute span sweeps and material take-offs - estimate embodied carbon and cost per m² - rank system families and export CSV/plots

docs.title: On this site
docs.text:
Use the left navigation (or tabs on top) to explore: - EDCA Overview — architecture, data model, implementation details - Getting Started — install + quick start example - Workflow — running and validating the tool - Developer Guide — structure, tests and contribution notes

If anything looks off, open an issue or a PR on the GitHub repo linked in the header.

-- This documentation was last updated February 2026 at 5:46PM GMT --

docs.title: EDCA Code and Foundations
docs.text:
• EDCA runs on Python
  • Data is in parquets
  • Based on various other tools
  • Various packages are listed all over
  • Things are in .py files
  • Data is in .parquet files
  • Optional user inputs can be added in .csv files
  • Key hardcoded information (schemas, code specs, properties) are in .yml files
  • Filetypes

  • User-Submitted Data (CSVs)

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
• create relevant load combos
  • determine which code is relevant
  • apply all the mathy math that can be extrapolated

docs.title: Inputs
docs.text:
• parse.py control file dataclass
  • specific code flag
  • loads from occupancy.csv

docs.title: Exports
docs.text:
• load combo and specific gamma values and final load values
  • per floor

docs.title: Code Pipeline
docs.text:
• happens after parse.py
  • used in systems.py
  • passes back through for code_checks.py

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: • parse the control file

docs.title: Inputs
docs.text:
• control file
  • key parameters

docs.title: Exports
docs.text: • functions and variables representing the parsed control file

docs.title: Code Pipeline
docs.text:
• things are inputted
  • they're separated using a read yaml function
  • they are assigned certain values
  • they're used later on all over

docs.title: Dataclasses
docs.text:
• control file dataclass
  • all of the rlevant data necessary is in this class

docs.title: Constraints
docs.text:
• very strict parsing
  • doesn't raise enough errors

docs.title: Control File Function
docs.text:
• The Control File governs everything else in the document
  • Parameters are parsed from this document
  • It includes defaults for future data, so it's necessary to have a complete CF without any missing data
  • It's parsed in parse.py and translated over to other data

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: • It's easy to edit just do it right

docs.title: Editing
docs.text:
• Using schemas as a baseline
  • Copying the data in there
  • Making sure everything follows preset units

docs.title: Inputting/Operating
docs.text:
• Make sure it maps to schemas
  • Put in specific folder filepaths
  • Make sure it's in there (and either commit it or leave it updated)
  • Don't change column names or placement

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
• Allowing computer understanding of each tool
  • Being super fast to process
  • Type guarantees and verification of results

docs.title: Foundation
docs.text: • Based on CSVs and schema

docs.title: Generation
docs.text:
• Don't touch them
  • The computer will do it all

docs.title: Operation
docs.text:

docs.title: Relationship to Source Data
docs.text:
• Backup for CSVs
  • Allows to keep it intact while eidintg CSVs
  • Need to consistently regenerate if you update CSVs

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
• Allowing some user input but more importantly being readable without edits
  • Being super accessible and understandable format
  • Hardcoded some data for reference

docs.title: Reference
docs.text:
• Just don't touch them (excluding the control file)
  • Useful for schemas

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: To operate the EDCA tool natively on your computer, the following steps are required. These instructions include downloading the EDCA codebase, installing relevant packages, and opening and operating the tool within a terminal/command line.
